text: (shortdesc)_1_The architectural specification portion of the DITA specification outlines the     framework of DITA. It contains an overview of DITA markup; addressing; processing;     configuration, specialization, generalization, and constraints; as well as information about     coding DITA grammar files.

title: ( ph)_0_process attribute resolve conref
text: (shortdesc)_1_When resolving conrefs, processors need to combine the attributes that are specified on     the referencing and referenced element.
subject: processor

title: ( ph)_0_process attribute resolve conref
text: The attribute specifications on the resolved element  (ph)_7_are  drawn       from both the referencing element and the referenced element, according to the following       priority:          (li)_8_All attributes as specified on the referencing element, except for attributes set to         "-dita-use-conref-target".      All attributes as specified on the referenced element except the  (xmlatt)_9_id          attribute.      The  (xmlatt)_10_xml:lang  attribute has special treatment as described in  .         The token  -dita-use-conref-target is defined by the specification to         enable easier use of  (xmlatt)_12_conref  on elements with required attributes.  The       only time the resolved element would include an attribute whose specified value is       "-dita-use-conref-target" is when the referenced element had that attribute specified with the       "-dita-use-conref-target" value and the referencing element either had no specification for       that attribute or had it also specified with the "-dita-use-conref-target" value. If the final       resolved element (after the complete resolution of any conref chain, as explained below) has       an attribute with the "-dita-use-conref-target" value, that element  (term)_13_MUST  be treated as equivalent to having that       attribute unspecified.     A given attribute value on the resolved element comes in its entirety from either the    referencing element or the referenced element; the attribute values of the referencing and    referenced elements for a given attribute are never additive, even if the property (such as      (xmlatt)_14_audience ) takes a list of values.     If the referenced element has a  (xmlatt)_15_conref  attribute specified, the above rules    should be applied recursively with the resolved element from one referencing/referenced    combination becoming one of the two elements participating in the next referencing/referenced    combination. The result should preserve without generalization all elements that are valid in the    originating context, even if they are not valid in an intermediate context.      (p)_16_For example, if topic A and topic C allow highlighting, and topic B does       not, then a content reference chain of topic A-to-topic B-to-topic C should preserve any       highlighting elements in the referenced content. The result, however it is achieved, must be       equivalent to the result of resolving the conref pairs recursively starting from the original       referencing element in topic A.

title: ( ph)_0_conref overview
text: (ph)_6_This topic  uses the definitions of   and   as defined in  .                         (dt)_10_Pulling content to the referencing element                       When the  (xmlatt)_11_conref  or  (xmlatt)_12_conkeyref  attribute is used alone,             the referencing element acts as a placeholder for the referenced element, and the             content of the referenced element is rendered in place of the referencing element.             The combination of the  (xmlatt)_13_conrefend  attribute with either                (xmlatt)_14_conref  or  (xmlatt)_15_conkeyref  specifies a range of elements             that is rendered in place of the referencing element.  (ph)_16_Although               the start and end elements must be of the same type as the referencing element (or               specialized from that element type), the elements inside the range can be any               type.                                     (dt)_17_Pushing content from the referencing element                       The  (xmlatt)_18_conaction  attribute reverses the direction of reuse from pull to             push.  With a push, the referencing element is rendered before,               after, or in place of the referenced element. The location (before, after, or in place               of) is determined by the value of the  (xmlatt)_19_conaction  attribute.              Because the  (xmlatt)_20_conaction  and  (xmlatt)_21_conrefend  attributes cannot             both be used within the same referencing element, it is not possible to push a range of             elements.                               (p)_22_A fragment of DITA content, such as an XML document that contains only a single paragraph       without a topic ancestor, does not contain enough information for the conref processor to be       able to determine the validity of a reference to it. Consequently, the value of a conref must       specify one of the following items:               (li)_23_A referenced element within a DITA map         (li)_24_A referenced element within a DITA topic         (li)_25_An entire DITA map         (li)_26_An entire DITA topic

title: ( ph)_0_process conref
text:
(ph)_8_Except where allowed by weak constraints, a conref processor (term)_9_MUST NOT permit resolution of a reuse relationship that could be rendered invalid under the rules of either the reused or reusing content.

We need to ensure that the above statement, modified as a result of the targeted review, fits with new content (still being added, as a result of the targeted review of the constraints material) about weak and strong constraints.

Also, Michael Priestley should review the statement; we (spec editors) know that he cares passionately about this area :)

 The DITA (xmlatt)_10_conref attribute (ph)_11_is a transclusion mechanism similar to XInclude and to HyTime value references. DITA differs from these mechanisms, however, in that conref validity does not apply simply to the current content at the time of replacement, but to the possible content given the restrictions of both the referencing document type and the referenced document type. When pulling content with the conref mechanism, if the referenced element is the same type as the referencing element, and the (ph)_12_set of domains declared on the (xmlatt)_13_domains attribute in the referenced topic or map instance is the same as or a subset of the domains declared in the referencing document, the element set allowed in the referenced element is guaranteed to be the same as, or a subset of, the element set allowed in the referencing element. When pushing content with the conref mechanism, the domain checking algorithm is reversed. In this case, if the set of domains declared on the (xmlatt)_14_domains attribute in the referencing topic or map instance is the same as or a subset of the domains declared in the referenced document, the element set allowed in the pushed content is guaranteed to be the same as, or a subset of, the element set allowed in the new location. In both cases, processors resolving conrefs (term)_15_SHOULD tolerate specializations of valid elements and generalize elements in the pushed or pulled content fragment as needed for the resolving context.

All replacement of content based on conref occurs after parsing of the document but prior to any styling or other transformational or presentational operations on the full topic.

text: (shortdesc)_1_Concept topics are specialized from topic. They include the standard topic elements, 		including the short description, prolog, a body, and related links.
subject: shortdesc)_1_concept topic

title: ( title)_0_concept topic
text:
(title)_2_The purpose of the concept information type Concepts provide background that helps readers understand essential information about a product, a task, a process, or any other conceptual or descriptive information. A concept (ph)_3_might be an extended definition of a major abstraction such as a process or function. Conceptual information (ph)_4_might explain the nature and components of a product and describe how it fits into a category of products. Conceptual information helps readers to map their knowledge and understanding to the tasks they need to perform and to provide other essential information about a product, process, or system. (title)_5_The structure of the concept topic The concept topic is specialized from the base topic information type. The top-level element for a DITA concept topic is the (xmlelement)_6_concept element. Every concept topic contains the standard topic elements, including title, short descriptions or abstract, prolog, a body, and related links. The (xmlelement)_7_conbody element holds the main body-level elements of the concept topic. Like the (xmlelement)_8_body element of a base topic, the (xmlelement)_9_conbody allows paragraphs, lists, tables, figures and other general elements. It also provides two key elements that allow authors to subdivide the topic into parts, with or without titles. These subdivisions are called sections and examples. The (xmlelement)_10_conbody also allows (xmlelement)_11_div , (xmlelement)_12_bodydiv , and (xmlelement)_13_sectiondiv to facilitate grouping elements in the (xmlelement)_14_conbody . Limitations within (xmlelement)_15_conbody The (xmlelement)_16_conbody provides for an unlimited number of subdivisions in the form of sections and examples. However, once an author decides to incorporate a section or example in the (xmlelement)_17_conbody , only additional sections or examples are allowed. Sections and examples (ph)_18_can not nest, meaning that only one level of subdivision is permitted in the concept topic. (title)_19_Concept body primary subdivisions (xmlelement)_20_section Represents an organizational division in a concept topic. Sections organize subsets of information within a larger topic. You can only include a simple list of peer sections in a topic; sections cannot be nested. A section (ph)_21_can have an optional title. (xmlelement)_22_example Provides examples that illustrate or support the current topic. The (xmlelement)_23_example element has the same content model as (xmlelement)_24_section . Following is an example of a simple concept topic. Note that once an example is used, it (ph)_25_can be followed only by another example or by a section. (codeblock)_26_ Bird Songs Bird songs are complex vocalizations used to attract mates or defend territories.

Bird songs vary widely among species, from simple songs that are genetically imprinted to complex songs that are learned over a lifetime.

Flycatchers know their songs from birth:

  • Flycatcher songs are simple sequences of notes.
  • Flycatcher songs never vary but are unique to each member of the Flycatcher family.
Modules

The following DITA modules are provided for the concept topic:

title: ( title)_0_general task topic
text: (shortdesc)_1_The general-task document type was introduced in DITA 1.2. It provides a less-strict 		content model for task-oriented information than was available previously. Some 		organizations might prefer the general-task content model over the strict task model, as it 		can facilitate the migration of legacy content that does not follow the strict-task topic 		model. The general-task document type serves as the base for the strict-task and 		machine-industry-task document types. It also can be used to create new document types or 		specializations.

title: ( title)_0_general task topic
text:
(title)_2_The purpose of the general task information type (p)_3_Like the DITA strict task document type, the general task document and information types contain the essential building blocks to provide procedural information. Both task information types answer the "How do I?" question by providing step-by-step instructions that detail the requirements that must be fulfilled, the actions that must be performed, and the order in which the actions must be performed. Both task topics include sections for describing the context, prerequisites, expected results, and other aspects of a task. The general task information type is specifically designed to accommodate task specializations that differ from the DITA task information type. It (ph)_4_might also be used for the conversion of loosely structured tasks from other sources into DITA before they are restructured to follow the more restrictive DITA task model. (title)_5_The structure of the general task topic The (xmlelement)_6_task element is the top-level element for the general task topic. The general task topic contains a (xmlelement)_7_title and a (xmlelement)_8_taskbody with optional alternative titles ( (xmlelement)_9_titlealts ), a short description or (xmlelement)_10_abstract , a (xmlelement)_11_prolog , and (xmlelement)_12_related-links . (p)_13_The following elements are described here because they are introduced as part of the general task model. All other elements are described in the strict task topic. (xmlelement)_14_section Represents an organizational division in a task topic. Sections organize subsets of information within the larger topic. Sections (ph)_15_cannot be nested. A section (ph)_16_can have an optional (xmlelement)_17_title . (xmlelement)_18_steps-informal Describes procedural task information that would not normally be ordered as (xmlelement)_19_steps , such as a group of general procedures that (ph)_20_might all be applied in a particular situation. Instead of (xmlelement)_21_step , the (xmlelement)_22_steps-informal element uses (xmlelement)_23_ol and (xmlelement)_24_ul elements, which are less strictly defined than the (xmlelement)_25_step element. When converting legacy content, it (ph)_26_might be simpler to convert numbered lists to (xmlelement)_27_ol elements than to (xmlelement)_28_step elements. (title)_29_Comparison of general and strict task (p)_30_The following table compares the structures of general and strict task: (entry)_33_General taskbody (entry)_34_Strict taskbody constraint (entry)_35_prerequisite (optional, in any order, any number) (entry)_36_prerequisite (optional, one only, must precede context) (entry)_37_context (optional, in any order, any number) (entry)_38_context (optional, one only, must follow prerequisite) (entry)_39_section (optional, in any order, any number) (entry)_40_(not defined for strict taskbody) (entry)_41_steps (entry)_42_steps (entry)_43_steps-unordered (entry)_44_steps-unordered (entry)_45_steps-informal (entry)_46_(not defined for strict taskbody) (entry)_47_result (optional, one only, precedes example) (entry)_48_result (optional, one only, precedes example) (entry)_49_example (optional, any number, precedes post-req) (entry)_50_example (optional, one only, precedes post-req) (entry)_51_post-requisite (optional, any number) (entry)_52_post-requisite (optional, one only)

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Each glossary entry  (xmlelement)_1_glossentry  topic defines a single sense of     one term. Besides identifying the term and providing a definition, the topic accommodates basic     terminology information, such as part of speech. A glossentry topic  (ph)_2_might  also include acronyms and acronym expansions. Glossentry topics can be assembled     by authors or processes to create glossaries for various purposes, including books, websites, or     other projects.
subject: xmlelement)_1_glossentry   topic
topic
glossentry topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text:
(title)_3_The purpose of the glossary entry topic (p)_4_Defining terminology in a glossary ensures that a team of writers uses the same term for the same concept. A glossary added to a book or available online in conjunction with other subject matter provides the reader with definitions of unfamiliar terms and expands acronyms. 1. from jeff ogden: Say a little more. Say that collections of glossary entries are assembled into collections of terms when they are referenced from a map. Say that the Glossary topic type was originally created for use with bookmap, but can be used elsewhere. 2. MP response: reluctant to say either - I'm not clear on what special processing maps could/would provide. Added a paragraph with the simple case (just author a glossary) below. On the "originally created for bookmap" front, I'm not sure I agree - one of the requirements going in from an IBM perspective was for online glossaries rather than book-based ones. 3.MP: per jeff ogden and per stan doherty, provided some extra text to clarify that glossary topics do go into glossaries (title)_5_The structure of the glossentry topic The top-level element for a DITA glossentry topic is the (xmlelement)_6_glossentry element. Every glossentry topic contains a (xmlelement)_7_glossterm and a (xmlelement)_8_glossdef element and optional (xmlelement)_9_related-links . Where a term has multiple definitions, (ph)_10_best practices call for the writer to create multiple glossentry topics with the same term in the (xmlelement)_11_glossterm element but different definitions in the (xmlelement)_12_glossdef element. A process can collate and group glossentry topics by term when generating formatted output. Note that definitions with the same term in one language can have different terms in other languages, so translations can result in different collation and grouping of the same set of glossentry topics. (p)_13_Here is an example of a simple glossentry topic: (codeblock)_14_ Data Definition Language A language used for defining database schemas. To create a glossary, authors can group multiple entries together by (li)_15_authoring in a single document using the Glossary group document type (li)_16_authoring in a single document under a container topic using the ditabase document type (li)_17_referencing the glossentry topics from a map (li)_18_using an automated process For example, an automated process (ph)_19_might assemble glossentry topics from a repository based on the (xmlelement)_20_term markup in a particular collection of topics. Jeff Ogden 2007/01/22: made authoring option using ditabase explicit; made automated processing option clearer with an example (title)_21_Acronyms defined within glossentry topics The glossentry topic (ph)_22_can be used to provide expansions of acronyms in online text and assist in the proper translation of acronyms into multiple languages. The acronym elements of the glossentry topic include the following: (li)_23_ to enter the full text to which the acronym refers (li)_24_ to provide the appropriate rendering of the full text plus the acronym in each language (li)_25_ to provide the acronym text itself (p)_26_Here is an example of an acronym used in the glossentry topic: (codeblock)_27_ Weapons of Mass Destruction Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD) WMD (p)_28_Here is an example of how the glossentry topic would be translated into Spanish: (codeblock)_29_ armas de destruccin masiva Note that because no acronym exists for the term in Spanish, the (xmlelement)_30_glossSurfaceForm and (xmlelement)_31_glossAcronym elements are left blank. (p)_32_In some languages, the surface form that expands the acronym in its first use handles the formatting differently than in English. For example, in Polish, the acronym precedes the expansion. (codeblock)_33_ Unia Europejska UE (Unia Europejska) UE For more information about the correct use of acronym expansions in multiple languages, see (i)_34_Best Practice for Managing Acronyms and Abbreviations in DITA , produced by the DITA Translation Subcommittee.
Modules

The following DITA modules are provided for the glossary entry topic. The glossary.dtd, glossary.ent, and glossary.mod are deprecated versions of the files glossentry.dtd., glossentry.ent, and glossentry.mod. The deprecated files are included in DITA 1.2 to provide backward compatibility with DITA 1.0 and 1.1.

title: ( title)_0_machinery task topic
text: (shortdesc)_1_The machinery task document type supports the development of instructions for the           completion of a procedure. The machinery task document type is built using the general           task information type combined with the Machinery Taskbody Constraint.
subject: shortdesc)_1_the machinery task document type
machinery task document type

title: ( title)_0_machinery task topic
text:
(title)_2_The purpose of the machinery task information type (p)_3_The machinery-task is designed to provide procedural information, similar to the strict task topic, and has a well-defined semantic structure that describes how to perform the steps required to accomplish a specific goal. Compared to the strict task information type, the machinery-task information type contains additional descriptive elements in the prelreqs section that add detail to the pre-requisites required to perform a task. The machinery-task topic is developed using the DITA constraint mechanism, in addition to specializations for new elements. (p)_4_Machinery tasks are the essential building blocks to provide procedural information for machines, machinery equipment, assemblies, and apparatuses. A machinery-task information type answers the "How do I?" question by providing precise step-by-step instructions detailing the requirements that must be fulfilled, the actions that must be performed, and the order in which the actions must be performed. The machinery-task topic includes sections for describing the context, preliminary requirements, expected results, examples, closing requirements, and other aspects of a task. (title)_5_The structure of the machinery-task topic Similar to a strict DITA task, the (xmlelement)_6_task element is the top-level element for a machinery task topic. The machinery task document type contains a title and a taskbody with optional alternative titles (titlealts), a short description or abstract, a prolog,and related-links. The (xmlelement)_7_taskbody element is the main body element inside a machinery-task topic. A machinery-task body has a very specific structure, with the following elements in this order: ( or (xmlelement)_8_context or (xmlelement)_9_section )*, (xmlelement)_10_steps , (xmlelement)_11_result , (xmlelement)_12_example , and (xmlelement)_13_closereqs . Each of the body sections is optional. The machinery task includes two specialized element groups: (xmlelement)_14_prelreqs and (xmlelement)_15_closereqs . All other element groups are the same as the general task model. (dt)_16_ The preliminary-requirements section of a task is used to describe what the user needs to know or do before starting the immediate task. The (xmlelement)_17_prelreqs element is similar to the prerequisites section of the general task model but contains a more descriptive content model. The (xmlelement)_18_prelreqs element contains required conditions, required personnel, required equipment, supplies, spares, and safety information. (dt)_19_ The close-requirements section is used to describe conditions that must be fulfilled after the successful completion of the current task. It is often supported by links to the next task or tasks in the (xmlelement)_20_related-links section. The (xmlelement)_21_closereqs element contains required conditions (xmlelement)_22_reqconds .
Modules

The following DITA modules are provided for the machinery task topic.

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: (shortdesc)_1_Reference topics are specialized from topic. They contain the standard topic elements, 		including title, short descriptions or abstract, prolog, a body, and related links.
subject: shortdesc)_1_reference topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text:
(title)_2_Purpose of the reference topic (p)_3_Reference topics provide data that supports users as they perform a task. Reference topics might provide lists and tables that include product specifications, parts lists, and other data that is often looked up rather than memorized. A reference topic also can describe commands in a programming language or required tools for a series of maintenance tasks. (p)_4_Reference topics provide quick access to fact-based information. In technical information, reference topics are used to list product specifications and parameters, provide essential data, and provide detailed information on subjects such as the commands in a programming language. Reference topics can contain any subject matter that has regular content, such as ingredients for food in recipes, bibliographic lists, catalog items, and so on. (title)_5_The structure of the reference topic The top-level element for a reference topic is the (xmlelement)_6_reference element. The (xmlelement)_7_refbody element contains the main body-level elements of the reference topic. Reference topics limit the body to tables (both simple and complex), property lists, syntax sections, generic sections, and examples. All of the elements of (xmlelement)_8_refbody are optional; they (ph)_9_can appear in any sequence and number. (title)_10_Limitations on the reference body The (xmlelement)_11_refbody provides for an unlimited number of subdivisions in the form of sections, examples, syntax sections, property lists, and tables. However, once an author decides to incorporate a section, example, property list, or syntax section in the refbody, only additional sections, examples, property lists, or syntax sections are allowed. Simple and complex tables (ph)_12_can appear within sections, examples, and syntax sections. They (ph)_13_cannot appear within the property list or simple or complex table sections. Sections, examples, syntax sections, table subdivisions, and property lists (ph)_14_cannot nest; only one level of subdivision is permitted in the reference topic. (title)_15_The elements in the reference body (xmlelement)_16_section Represents an organizational division in a reference topic. Sections organize subsets of information within a larger topic. You can only include a simple list of peer sections in a topic; sections cannot be nested. A section (ph)_17_might have an optional title. (xmlelement)_18_refsyn Contains syntax or signature content (for example, a command-line utility's calling syntax or an API's signature). The (xmlelement)_19_refsyn contains a brief, possibly diagrammatic description of the subject's interface or high-level structure. (xmlelement)_20_example Provides examples that illustrate or support the current topic. The (xmlelement)_21_example element has the same content model as (xmlelement)_22_section . (xmlelement)_23_table (dd)_24_Organizes information according into a rows and columns. Table markup also allows for more complex structures, including spanning rows and columns, as well as table captions. (xmlelement)_25_simpletable (dd)_26_Holds information in regular rows and columns and does not allow a caption. (xmlelement)_27_properties (dd)_28_Lists properties of a subject and their types, values, and descriptions. Following is an example of a simple reference topic, including the (xmlelement)_29_refsyn element. Bold = trueorfalse Data type Boolean Legal values True (1) or False (0) Following is an example of a simple reference topic, including the (xmlelement)_31_property element. title: ( title)_0_bookmap
text: (shortdesc)_1_The DITA bookmap specialization represents the key markup requirements for managing     DITA content through book-oriented publication processes, including book metadata and book     structures for organizing content.
subject: shortdesc)_1_the dita bookmap specialization

title: ( title)_0_bookmap
text:
(title)_2_The purpose of the bookmap specialization (p)_3_Books and other printed media are popular ways to present DITA content. By specializing the general DITA map structure into the general structure and subject areas used by most book-oriented DTDs, bookmaps enable users to organize their DITA information into front matter, parts, chapters, and so forth. A rich set of metadata allows for recording information about the book, such as its authors and owners, versions, and production history. (title)_4_The structure of the bookmap specialization The (xmlelement)_5_bookmap element is the top-level element for a DITA bookmap. Most of the content for a bookmap is optional, allowing for specializations that further restrict the bookmap model. (p)_6_A bookmap allows the following parts: (li)_7_An initial title or booktitle (booktitle has more semantics) (li)_8_Book metadata (publisher, author, copyright holders and dates, etc.) (li)_9_Front matter (placement for Table of Contents and other preliminary information) (li)_10_Any number of chapters or parts (parts can group chapters, chapters can group topics) (li)_11_An appendices section (similar to a part or a chapter, can group multiple appendices) (li)_12_Back matter (similar to front matter, notices, glossary, index, etc.) (li)_13_Relationship table (p)_14_In book-oriented XML grammars, authors typically manage content structures as external entities, separate from the body of the book and referenced as embedded elements into the overall structure. Bookmap follows the same organizational approach, using the topicref-based structure of DITA maps as the archetype for the major divisions of a book. (p)_15_Here is an example of a simple bookmap. It uses several mechanisms to include chapter content: (li)_16_Referencing a DITA map (li)_17_Referencing a DITA topic Nesting (xmlelement)_18_topicref elements (codeblock)_19_ Product tasks Tasks and what they do John Doe 2006 Jane Doe
Modules

The following DITA modules are provided for the bookmap specialization.

The strict-task document type is built using the general-task 		information type combined with the strict taskbody constraint. See the reference below to 		ensure that you have the correct task document type when you update to DITA 1.3 from DITA 		1.0 or DITA 1.1
subject: shortdesc)_1_the strict task - document type
strict - task document type

title: ( title)_0_task topic ( strict task )
text:
(title)_2_The purpose of the standard task information type Tasks are the essential building blocks to provide procedural information. A task information type answers the "How do I?" question by providing precise step-by-step instructions detailing the requirements that must be fulfilled, the actions that must be performed, and the order in which the actions must be performed. The (xmlelement)_3_task topic includes sections for describing the context, prerequisites, expected results, and other aspects of a task. The structure of the (xmlelement)_4_task topic The (xmlelement)_5_task element is the top-level element for the strict task topic. The strict task document type contains a (xmlelement)_6_title and a (xmlelement)_7_taskbody with optional alternative titles ( (xmlelement)_8_titlealts ), a short description or (xmlelement)_9_abstract , a (xmlelement)_10_prolog , and (xmlelement)_11_related-links . The (xmlelement)_12_taskbody element is the main body element inside a strict task document type. The strict task body has a constrained structure, with these optional elements in the following order: (xmlelement)_13_prereq Describes information that the user needs to know or do before starting the immediate task. This section (ph)_14_can occur only once. (xmlelement)_15_context Provides background information for the task. This information helps the users understand the purpose of the task and what they will gain by completing the task correctly. This section should be brief and does not replace or recreate a concept topic on the same subject, although the context section (ph)_16_might include some conceptual information. This section (ph)_17_can occur only once. (xmlelement)_18_steps Provides the main content of the task topic. A (xmlelement)_19_task consists of a series of steps that accomplish the task. The (xmlelement)_20_steps element must have one or more (xmlelement)_21_step elements, which provide the specifics about each step in the task. The (xmlelement)_22_steps element (ph)_23_can occur only once. The (xmlelement)_24_step element represents an action that a user must follow to accomplish a task. Each (xmlelement)_25_step in a (xmlelement)_26_task must contain a command (xmlelement)_27_cmd element which describes the particular action the user must perform to accomplish the overall task. The (xmlelement)_28_step element (ph)_29_can also contain information (xmlelement)_30_info , substeps (xmlelement)_31_substeps , tutorial information (xmlelement)_32_tutorialinfo , a step example (xmlelement)_33_stepxmp , choices (xmlelement)_34_choices , a step result (xmlelement)_35_stepresult , or troubleshooting (xmlelement)_36_steptroubleshooting , although these are optional. (xmlelement)_37_steps-unordered Provides alternative content for the (xmlelement)_38_task topic, allowing for a single step in a procedure or a set of commands that need not be performed in a specific order. (xmlelement)_39_result (dd)_40_Describes the expected outcome for the task as a whole. (xmlelement)_41_example (dd)_42_Provides an example that illustrates or supports the task. (xmlelement)_43_postreq Describes steps or tasks that the user should do after the successful completion of the current task. It is often supported by links to the next task or tasks in the (xmlelement)_44_related-links section. Here is an example of a task topic: (codeblock)_45_ Building a bird house Building a birdhouse is a perfect activity for adults to share with their children or grandchildren. It can be used to teach about birds, as well as the proper use of tools. Birdhouses provide safe locations for birds to build nests and raise their young. They also provide shelter during cold and rainy spells. To build a sound birdhouse, you will need a complete set of tools:
  • hand saw
  • hammer ...
Lay out the dimensions for the birdhouse elements. Cut the elements to size. Drill a 1 1/2" diameter hole for the bird entrance on the front. You need to look at the drawing for the correct placement of the hole. You now have a beautiful new birdhouse! Now find a good place to mount it. (title)_46_Maintaining specializations using the strict task model Organizations that have created specializations based on the DITA 1.0 and 1.1 strict task model (ph)_47_can review the recommendations in (ph)_49_for information about how to maintain their specializations.

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The Technical Content package contains various document types: 	 concept, reference, general task, strict task, machinery task,  	  (ph)_1_troubleshooting , glossary entry, and 	 glossary group. These document types are designed specifically for information 	 that describes how to use products and processes. The Technical Content package 	 also includes the map document type.
subject: technical content package
document type
technical content package

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
Concept

The concept document type provides conceptual information designed to support the performance of tasks. Concepts might include extended definitions of terms, expositions of background information, descriptions of systems and objects, and other content that helps to build the users' understanding of the tasks to be perform.

Reference

The reference document type provides for the separation of fact-based information from concepts and tasks. Factual information might include tables and lists of specifications, parameters, parts, commands, and other information that the users are likely to look up. The reference document type enables fact-based content to be maintained by those responsible for its accuracy and consistency.

Task (strict task)

The task document type provides procedural information to support the performance of a task. The task document type is built by combining the general-task document type and the strict taskbody constraint. This information model provides detailed semantics to encourage authors to label standard parts of the task, including prerequisites, sufficient conceptual information required to perform the task, the commands that introduce each step in a procedure, additional support information required to understand a step, the result of performing the task, and examples that demonstrate the performance of the task.

General task

The general-task document type provides a less strict task model for task-oriented information than that provided in the strict task. Some organizations might prefer the general task model; it can facilitate the migration of legacy task content that does not follow the strict task topic model. The general-task document type serves as the base for the strict task and machine-industry-task document types.

For historical reasons and to maintain backward compatibility, the names used for the various task components can be confusing:

  • General task is the name for the general task document type
  • Task is the name for the strict task document type
  • Task is also the name for the general task information type
  • Task is the name of the specialized topic tag in the general information type which is used in the strict task, general task, and machine-industry task document types
Machinery task

The machinery-task document type provides procedural information, similar to other task types; it has a well-defined semantic structure to meet the special requirements of organizations that develop instructional material for industrial equipment, such as trucks, mining machinery, and automobiles. The machine-industry task requirements domain adds several descriptive elements in the preliminary requirements (prelreqs) and closing requirements (closereqs) sections. The machinery-task document type is built by combining the general-task document type with the task requirements domain and the machinery taskbody constraint.

Troubleshooting

The troubleshooting document type provides markup for corrective action information such as troubleshooting and alarm clearing. The troubleshooting information type describes a condition or a symptom, after which it provides one or more possible causes and their associated remedies. Each remedy is a series of steps, associated with a cause, that attempts to resolve the condition or symptom.

Glossary entry

The glossary entry (glossentry) document type enables authors to develop glossary topics that define terms, acronyms, and abbreviations. It also can contain terminology information.

Glossary group

The glossary group (glossgroup) document type enables authors to incorporate multiple glossary entries in a single collection tile.

title: ( title)_0_troubleshoot topic
text: (shortdesc)_1_The troubleshooting topic type provides markup for corrective action information such 		as troubleshooting and alarm clearing.
subject: shortdesc)_1_the troubleshooting topic type

title: ( title)_0_troubleshoot topic
text:
(title)_2_The troubleshooting information type (p)_3_In its simplest form, troubleshooting information follows this pattern: (li)_4_A condition or symptom. Usually the condition or symptom is an undesirable state in a system, a product, or a service that a reader wants to correct. (li)_5_A cause for the condition or symptom. (li)_6_A remedy for the condition or symptom. (p)_7_The troubleshooting topic provides sections for describing the condition, causes, and remedies needed to restore a system, a product, or a service to normal. (p)_8_For some conditions there could be more than one cause-remedy pair. The troubleshooting topic accommodates this. Typically, a cause is immediately followed by its remedy. Multiple cause-remedy pairs can provide a series of successive fall-backs for resolving a condition. (p)_9_Cause and remedy might occur in combinations other than pairs. It is possible to have: (li)_10_Multiple causes with the same remedy (li)_11_A single cause with more than one remedy (li)_12_A remedy with no known cause (li)_13_A cause with no known remedy (p)_14_The troubleshooting information type also can be used to document alarm clearing strategies. (title)_15_The structure of the troubleshooting topic The top-level element for troubleshooting topics is (xmlelement)_16_troubleshooting . The (xmlelement)_17_troubleshooting element contains a (xmlelement)_18_title with optional alternative titles ( (xmlelement)_19_titlealts ), a short description or (xmlelement)_20_abstract , a (xmlelement)_21_prolog , a (xmlelement)_22_troublebody , and (xmlelement)_23_related-links . (xmlelement)_24_troublebody is the main body element in a troubleshooting topic. The (xmlelement)_25_troublebody element contains the following elements: (xmlelement)_26_condition This optional element is the first child of (xmlelement)_27_troublebody , and it describes a condition or symptom that is associated with an undesirable state in a system, a product, or a service. In cases where the topic title fully explains the condition, (ph)_28_do not use this element. (xmlelement)_29_troubleSolution One or more (xmlelement)_30_troubleSolution elements must appear in the (xmlelement)_31_troublebody element. (xmlelement)_32_troubleSolution is a wrapper element for (xmlelement)_33_cause and (xmlelement)_34_remedy , each of which are a cause-remedy pair. The (xmlelement)_35_troubleSolution element contains the following elements: (xmlelement)_36_cause This optional, repeatable, first-child of (xmlelement)_37_condition (xmlelement)_38_troubleSolution describes a possible cause for the condition. (xmlelement)_39_remedy This optional, repeatable, last-child of (xmlelement)_40_troubleSolution describes a possible remedy for the condition. The (xmlelement)_41_remedy element begins with an optional (xmlelement)_42_title element followed by an optional (xmlelement)_43_responsibleParty element followed by either a (xmlelement)_44_steps element, a (xmlelement)_45_steps-unordered element, or a (xmlelement)_46_steps-informal element. The content models for (xmlelement)_47_steps , (xmlelement)_48_steps-unordered , and (xmlelement)_49_steps-informal are borrowed from (xmlelement)_50_task . This allows remedy to reuse steps from tasks. (dt)_51_ This optional first child of (xmlelement)_52_remedy indicates who is expected to perform the steps that are outlined in the (xmlelement)_53_remedy element. (p)_54_Here is an example of a troubleshooting topic: (codeblock)_55_ Cannot log on Login attempts have failed

The system does not accept your login credentials.

The CapsLock key might be on.

 Verify that the CapsLock key is off. Wrong password

The password that you are using does not match the one that is stored in the system.

 Open a Web browser window Go to Account management, and follow the instructions Unknown account name

The account name you are using does not match the one stored in the system.

 Still cannot log on

If none of the previous solutions work, consider asking for help. Contact your system administrator if your organization has one; otherwise, contact our support team.

title: ( title)_0_a learning object approach learn and train content
text: (shortdesc)_1_The DITA learning and training specializations apply DITA 	 principles and best practices for using topic-based and modular content to 	 plan, develop, and deliver learning and training content.
subject: shortdesc)_1_the dita learning and training specialization

title: ( title)_0_a learning object approach learn and train content
text: (p)_2_The reusable learning objects, or RLO, approach to learning content 		  derives from the pioneering work of learning content designers at several 		  companies, including Autodesk, Oracle, and Cisco. Author Peder Jacobsen 		  defines an RLO as "a discrete reusable collection of content used to present 		  and support a single learning objective." With this approach, it is possible to 		  gather a pool of information objects and make them available for reuse and 		  repurposing in a variety of learning delivery contexts.   		 (p)_3_There is a strong affinity between the DITA topic-based, modular 		  approach to content in general, and the learning objects approach to learning 		  content in particular.   		 Working assumptions about learning content and how to support 		  authoring and delivering it with DITA include the following:  		   		   (li)_4_The DITA Learning and 			 Training specialization builds on a reusable learning objects (RLO) approach to 			 learning content.   		   DITA  			  (b)_5_topic types  are the basic building blocks for learning objects 			 and specify the meaning and intention of content provided in instructional and 			 information objects.  		     		   DITA  			  (b)_6_domains  provide the mechanism for defining  			  (i)_7_interactions , which can be used across the learning topic 			 types.  		     		   DITA  			  (b)_8_domains  also provide the mechanism for defining learning  			  (i)_9_metadata , which can be assigned either in topics or in maps.  		     		   DITA  			  (b)_10_maps  arrange the DITA learning topics into a hierarchy of 			 learning objects and group such content for delivery as lessons, modules, and 			 courses.  		     		   DITA  			  (b)_11_specialization provides the mechanism for creating the learning-based topic 			 types, domains, and maps needed for instructional and information object 			 content requirements.  		     		   		   		   		   (title)_12_Learning objects and specialized DITA learning and training 			 topic types   		   (p)_13_This figure shows the composition of learning objects as a) 			 instructional objects, b) information objects, and c) the specialized DITA 			 topic types to support them.   		     			  (alt)_14_Box diagram that shows the relationship 				between learning and training objects and the DITA-defined learning types that 				represent them. The Learning objects box shows instructional objects Overview, 				Content, Summary, and Assessments; the Content object is expanded in another 				box 'Information objects' including Concept, Task, Reference, Facts, Concepts, 				Procedures, and Principles. A DITA learning types box lists learningPlan, 				learningOverview, learningContent, learningSummary, and learningAssessment. 				Colors of the learning objects correlate to matching colors of the DITA 				learning types; for example, the Summary learning object and the 				learningSummary DITA type are both colored gold.   		     		   In this approach, a learning object comprises a "discrete reusable 			 collection of content used to present and support a single learning objective," 			 and consists of two primary information components:  		     			  (b)_15_instructional 				  objects , which provide the structured framework for a learning experience. 				The  (xmlelement)_16_learningOverview , 				 (xmlelement)_17_learningSummary , and 				 (xmlelement)_18_learningAssessment  topic types provide content for 				instructional objects.  			    			  (b)_19_information 				  objects , which provide the source learning content - the topic-based 				learning content and other supplemental content that supports the learning 				goals identified in the instructional objects. The 				 (xmlelement)_20_learningContent  topic type provides content for 				information objects.  			    			  (b)_21_instructional 				  plans , which identify the learning goals, needs, and objectives. The 				 (xmlelement)_22_learningPlan  topic type provides content for 				instructional plans.  			    		     		     		   		   		   (title)_23_Learning content design, authoring, and delivery through DITA 			 specialization   		   This picture shows the end-to-end process for designing, authoring, 			 and delivering specialized learning content with DITA.  			    				 (alt)_24_Labeled flowchart-style diagram; across 				  the middle horizontally are four primary stages of the flowchart with arrows 				  from stage to stage. Across the top and bottom are 5 numbered labels, pointing 				  to locations in the 4 stages, with text explaining what happens at each stage. 				  (See text content following diagram.) The first stage shows a miniature tree 				  diagram signifying a hierarchically-structured set of DITA topics. The second 				  stage shows a collection of file objects signifying learning topics. The third 				  stage shows a tree structure diagram as well as a table diagram. The fourth 				  stage lists the following learning deliverable types: Tutorials, Courseware 				  & e-learning, ILTs, CBTs, WBTs, SCORMS.   			    		     		   In this approach, a learning content developer:  		     			  Uses  				 (b)_25_learning map elements  to identify the learning objects and 				the supporting content needed to address specific learning goals and 				objectives.  			    			  Uses  				 (b)_26_learning topic elements  to structure the learning content.  			    			  Applies  				 (b)_27_learning metadata elements  to describe specific 				characteristics of the learning content, following a sub-set of the IEEE LOM 				standard.  			    			  Constructs  				 (b)_28_specific build maps and relationship tables  to organize 				learning objects for delivery as a course with specific output and delivery 				needs.  			    			  Invokes  				 (b)_29_processing  to generate specific learning deliverables, based 				on the default processing available with DITA content and specialized as needed 				for learning-specific purposes and delivery formats.

title: ( title)_0_support learningdomain1 and learningdomain2
text: (shortdesc)_1_Many questions require multiple block elements for the question 		statement ("prompt" or "stimulus" in instructional design parlance) and for feedback. The 		DITA 1.2 interaction design, learningDomain (and referred to informally as "learning 1"), 		only allows for a single paragraph question and single-paragraph feedback. The 		learningDomain2 design allows block elements with question statements, answer content, and 		feedback.
subject: shortdesc)_1_many question
dita 1.2 interaction design
learningdomain2 design

title: ( title)_0_support learningdomain1 and learningdomain2
text: The DITA 1.3 learningDomain2 		support deprecates the DITA 1.2 learningDomain1, but enables backward 		compatibility by redefining the  (xmlelement)_2_learningAssessment  		topic with the option of using either the DITA 1.2 support or the DITA 1.3 		support or both.  	   		 (note)_3_The OASIS-provided document-type shells that integrate the learning 			domains integrate both the learning and learning2 domains. The learning and training 			modules include constraint modules that allow only the learning or only the learning2 			domain; these constraint modules can be integrated into custom document-type 			shells.   	    		 (title)_4_learningDomain2   		 (p)_5_DITA 1.3 defines two new domains for the learning and 				training vocabulary: interactionBase2Domain and learning2Domain. These two new 				domains mirror the existing interactionBase and learning domains, but they provide a 				base model that allows multi-paragraph questions, answers, and feedback. The new 				domains are otherwise semantically identical to the original domains.   		   		     			  (dt)_6_learningInteractionBase2Domain   			    				   				     					  (xmlelement)_7_lcInteractionBase2   					    					    						 The 						   (xmlelement)_8_lcInteractionBase2  element differs from 						   (xmlelement)_9_lcInteractionBase  as follows:  						   						   						   Is a 							 specialization of  (xmlelement)_10_div  rather than 							  (xmlelement)_11_fig . It removes the content limitations that were 							 imposed by  (xmlelement)_12_fig , such as the inability to include 							  (xmlelement)_13_table . The 1.3 specialization allows all content 							 allowed in  (xmlelement)_14_div .  						     						   Uses 							  (xmlelement)_15_lcQuestionBase2  in place of 							  (xmlelement)_16_lcQuestionBase  to allow multiple paragraphs within its 							 content.  						     						   Makes  (xmlatt)_17_id  attribute optional for all interactions. (xmlelement)_22_div  allows 						all content that occurs in  (xmlelement)_23_body  except 						 (xmlelement)_24_section  and  (xmlelement)_25_bodydiv . This element is necessary because 						 (xmlelement)_30_div  does not allow  (xmlelement)_31_title . It defines new versions of each of the interaction types, each of which are 				specialized from  (xmlelement)_33_lcInteractionBase2 . The 				learning2Domain is not dependent on the original learningDomain. The 				learning2Domain can be used by itself or integrated along with the 				learningDomain.

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization
text: (shortdesc)_1_The DITA learning and training specializations build on best practices for modular content design, following DITA principles.
subject: dita learning

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization
text: The objectives of the specializations include the following:   Provide a general top-level design for authoring of education content with good learning architecture, following DITA principles and best practices.   Some specifics of good DITA design for learning content include:    (li)_2_offer a starter set of specialized topic types that support structured, intent-based authoring of content for learning and training, including assessments   provide a map domain for structuring  (ph)_3_and storing  the specialized          learning topics as reusable learning objects, and for managing the linking and          relationships among them   (li)_4_offers basic map-driven processing to support topic linking, relationships, and simple sequencing   (li)_5_includes a starter set of commonly-used learning interactions, for use in testing and assessment   (li)_6_provides support for learning metadata based on the IEEE standard for learning objects metadata (LOM), for use in both topics and maps         Establish guidelines that promote best practices for applying standard DITA approaches to learning content, which include:    (li)_7_separation of presentation and content (as much as possible)   (li)_8_separation of content and context   (li)_9_single sourcing, repurposing, and reuse       (li)_10_Provide basic support for processing DITA content for delivery as learning and training in a variety of forms, including print and presentation delivery to support instructor-led training (ILT) and web delivery for distance learning.   (li)_11_Provide a framework for developing targeted support for processing DITA learning content for delivery with standards-based learning, specifically targeting SCORM. Extend DITA processing to support basic SCORM packaging and required SCORM LMS runtime behaviors. Build on best practices for behaviors to drive and present the interactions.   (li)_12_Build on existing DITA infrastructures as much as possible, so learning content developers do not have to start from scratch because with minimal adaptation they can use standard approaches for DITA content and reuse content previously developed for other purposes.        (note)_13_Simply using the content models described in this specification, of course, does not ensure quality learning content. Quality learning content only results from good instructional design and in-depth learning needs analysis.

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (shortdesc)_1_The DITA learning and training specializations address several important requirements facing   developers and consumers of instructional content.
subject: dita learning

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (p)_2_Today's learners confront a complex world with many inter-related bits and pieces of information, many different ways to access that information, and a strong need to identify the connection points, the objectives, and the context for what to know and what to learn. In this environment, developers of learning and training content face many challenges, including:   (li)_3_How to find the context for developing and delivering the right content to the right person at the right time?   (li)_4_How to identify the learning goals and objectives?   (li)_5_Who and how many are the audiences?   (li)_6_How to pull together and integrate content from many different sources and content providers?   (li)_7_How to enable customers and partners to add, integrate, assemble, and deliver their own content?   These key challenges and issues for delivery of learning and training content mirror long-standing pain points and requirements for content delivery in general.    (li)_8_Content consumers value consistency of content and learning experiences.   (li)_9_They desire management of content to make it shareable across and within teams.   (li)_10_They seek to simplify the information needed to support the complex environments.   (li)_11_Finally, they want a content development process that can enable the assembly and delivery of custom content that addresses specific learning contexts and use cases.

(p)_7_If you have already implemented learning and 			training support with DITA 1.2 and none of the limitations adversely affected your 			support, then you can continue to use the learningDomain in document types that need 			assessments.

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: (shortdesc)_1_Several use cases inform the design and development of the DITA learning and training   specializations.
subject: shortdesc)_1_several use case

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: (dt)_2_Enable indexing, searching, and retrieval of learning content        (dd)_3_By structuring content with DITA topics and maps as self-contained learning objects that       are matched with appropriate DITA metadata, it is possible to enable fast indexing, search,       and retrieval of learning content that meets specific learning goals and objectives.                    (dt)_4_Creating custom courses quickly        (dd)_5_A company has a large inventory of topic-based content that is used to provide technical       and troubleshooting information about a set of componentized software products. The company       wants to enable field engineers to quickly identify technical content that is suitable for       providing on-site training. The DITA learning and training specializations enable field       engineers to draw on their inventory of topics and quickly assemble learning content to meet       specific customer needs.                    (dt)_6_Making technical content available for direct sharing and reuse in learning and       training        (dd)_7_A DITA learning specialization makes it possible to define a context for and directly       assemble and use existing technical content for delivery as learning and training. The DITA       approach identifies consistent structures and patterns and leverages them to enable a       consistent approach for sharing content across teams. The result is much more opportunity to       share content between different providers and across areas of expertise, to learn from each       other, and to deliver content and the learning experience consistently. As a result, instead       of copy, paste, and make unique as the norm, we have write once and share with others as the       new norm.                    (dt)_8_Creating tests and test preparation material        (dd)_9_A company publishes test preparation books that support students who are preparing for       standardized tests. The company maintains a library of thousands of questions from which they       can produce sample tests and set preparation materials for a specific test, grade level,       region, and more. The company uses classifying metadata within the questions to associate them       with the subjects, learning standards, grade levels, specific and standardized tests to which       the questions apply. Using this metadata, they can quickly find relevant questions when       developing new or updated publications. The questions include not just the question text but       also indication of the correct answer, feedback for correct and incorrect answers, and       feedback on the question as a whole. The learning interaction specializations make it possible       to create and manage this library of questions. Because the interaction structures have been       designed to be consistent with standards for electronic testing, the questions can be used to       produce both print publications and interactive online learning and testing deliverables.

title: ( title)_0_summary learn topic , map , and domain design
text: (shortdesc)_1_The DITA learning and training specializations provide a set of 	 specialized DITA topics, a learning interactions domain, a learning metadata 	 domain, and a learning map domain to support creating and delivering structured 	 learning content.
subject: dita learning

title: ( title)_0_summary learn topic , map , and domain design
text: (title)_2_Learning topic types  			 (p)_3_The following specialized DITA topic types provide support for creating learning and 				training content.  			  				  					 (dt)_4_Learning Plan topic type  					 (dd)_5_Describes learning needs and goals, instructional design models, task 						analyses, learning taxonomies, and other information necessary to the lesson 						planning process.  				  				  					 (dt)_6_Learning Overview topic type  					 (dd)_7_Identifies the learning objectives and includes other information helpful to 						the learner, such prerequisites, duration, and intended audience.  				  				  					 (dt)_8_Learning Content topic type  					 (dd)_9_Provides the learning content itself and enables direct use of content from 						DITA task, concept, and reference topics, as well as additional content of 						any topic type that supports specific objectives declared in the Learning 						Overview topic type.  				  				  					 (dt)_10_Learning Summary topic type  					 (dd)_11_Recaps and provides context for the learning objectives and provides 						guidance to reinforce learning and long-term memory.  				  				  					 (dt)_12_Learning Assessment topic type  					 (dd)_13_Presents instruments that measure progress, encourage retrieval, and 						stimulate reinforcement of the learning content and can be presented before 						the content as a pre-assessment or after the content as a post-assessment 						checkpoint or test.  				  			  		   	    		 (title)_14_Learning map types   		   		     			  (xmlelement)_15_learningGroupMap  			    			  A map container to enable  (xmlelement)_16_learningGroup  elements to be stored as 						separate objects and referenced by maps.    		     		     			  (xmlelement)_17_learningObjectMap  			    			  A map container to enable  (xmlelement)_18_learningObject  elements to be stored as 						separate objects and referenced by maps.    		     		   	    	    		 (title)_19_Learning map domain   		 (p)_20_Use the learning map domain to organize groups of topics as learning 		  objects.   		 The learning map domain is part of the 		   (xmlelement)_21_learningMap  and the 		   (xmlelement)_22_learningBookmap  document types. As these learning map 		  structures are delivered as a domain specialization rather than as a structural 		  specialization, it is possible to extend any type of DITA map to include these 		  structures. 		   		   		     			  (xmlelement)_23_learningGroup  			    			  A map container and optional topic reference to introduce and 				group learning objects into higher-level organizations, such as course-level, 				module-level, or lesson-level. A  (xmlelement)_24_learningGroup  can 				contain other  (xmlelement)_25_learningGroup  elements, allowing you to 				organize learning content at course, module, or other higher levels of 				hierarchy. 			    		     		     			  (xmlelement)_26_learningObject  			    			  (dd)_27_A map container and optional topic reference to introduce and 				group the topic references for a learning object.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_28_learningPlanRef  			    			  (dd)_29_A topic reference to a learning plan or other topic that provides 				the learning plan.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_30_learningOverviewRef  			    			  (dd)_31_A topic reference to a learning overview or other topic that 				introduces the learning object.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_32_learningContentRef  			    			  (dd)_33_A topic reference to a learning content topic, or a topic, task, 				concept, reference or other specialized topic.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_34_learningContentComponentRef  			    			  (dd)_35_A topic reference to a learning content topic, or a topic, task, 				concept, reference or other specialized topic.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_36_learningSummaryRef  			    			  (dd)_37_A topic reference to a learning summary or other topic that 				provides the summary.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_38_learningPreAssessmentRef  			    			  (dd)_39_A topic reference to a learning assessment or other topic that is 				used as a pre-assessment.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_40_learningPostAssessmentRef  			    			  (dd)_41_A topic reference to a learning assessment or other topic that is 				used as a post-assessment.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_42_learningObjectMapRef  			    			  (dd)_43_A topic reference to a learning object.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_44_learningGroupMapRef  			    			  (dd)_45_A topic reference to a learning group map   		     		   	    	    		 (title)_46_Learning interactions domain   		 The learning 		  interactions domain defines a set of basic learning interaction elements as a 		  DITA domain. Although there are two sets of elements for interaction support, 		  the recommended set is defined in the learningDomain2 support provided in DITA 		  1.3, which supports block elements. This support deprecates original DITA 1.2 		  elements, which failed to allow block elements where needed. See  		   lc-spec-Overview-domains.dita . 		   		   		   		     			  (xmlelement)_48_lcOpenQuestion2  			    			  (dd)_49_Poses an open-ended question in an assessment interaction.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_50_lcTrueFalse2  			    			  (dd)_51_Presents the learner with two choices, one correct, the other 				incorrect, often presented as true/false or yes/no responses.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_52_lcSingleSelect2  			    			  (dd)_53_Presents three or more choices, only one of which is correct.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_54_lcMultipleSelect2  			    			  (dd)_55_Presents two or more choices, two or more of which are correct.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_56_lcMatching2  			    			  (dd)_57_In a list of paired choices, the learner identifies the correct 				choice that matches another choice.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_58_lcHotspot2  			    			  (dd)_59_Presents an image, and the learner clicks on one or more regions 				to indicate a choice.   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_60_lcSequencing2  			    			  (dd)_61_Presents choices in a list that the learner must arrange in a 				correct ordered sequence.   		     		   		   	    	    		 (title)_62_Learning metadata domain   		 The learning metadata domain defines a set of basic learning metadata 		  elements as a DITA domain and available for use in the learning topic types, as 		  specialized  (xmlelement)_63_prolog  metadata and in the learning map 		  domain, as specialized  (xmlelement)_64_topicmeta . 		   		 (xmlelement)_65_lcLom  makes the learning 		  metadata elements available in the learning topics and learning map domain. 		   		 Elements in  (xmlelement)_66_lcLom  		  include: 		   		   (xmlelement)_67_lomAggregationLevel  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_68_lomContext   		     		   (xmlelement)_69_lomCoverage   		     		   (xmlelement)_70_lomDifficulty  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_71_lomInstallationRemarks  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_72_lomIntendedUserRole  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_73_lomInteractivityLevel  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_74_lomInteractivityType  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_75_lomLearningResourceType  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_76_lomOtherPlatformRequirements  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_77_lomSemanticDensity  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_78_lomStructure   		     		   (xmlelement)_79_lomTechRequirement  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_80_lomTypicalAgeRange  			  		     		   (xmlelement)_81_lomTypicalLearningTime  		     		  		   	    	    		 (title)_82_Instructor notes   		 The learning interactions domain also makes available an 		   (xmlelement)_83_lcInstructornote  element for providing 		  instructor-specific information.

title: ( title)_0_mathml and equation domain
text: (shortdesc)_1_The MathML and equation domains provide general containers for equations (inline, block,   and display) and an integration with the MathML standard. The equation containers identify   equations separate from the data that provides the equation content, which might take many forms,   including MathML markup, images, and non-XML formats like TeX and ASCII equations.

title: ( title)_0_mathml and equation domain
text: (p)_2_These two domains provide support for mathematics elements:                (dt)_3_MathML domain       Provides the  (xmlelement)_4_mathml  element, which is a specialization of        (xmlelement)_5_foreign . The  (xmlelement)_6_mathml  element can contain      direct MathML markup, or it can use the  (xmlelement)_7_mathmlref  element to include      MathML markup that is stored in a separate, non-DITA document. When this domain is integrated      without additional constraints, the  (xmlelement)_8_mathml  element is allowed wherever        (xmlelement)_9_foreign  is allowed.        The equation domain elements can be used to distinguish equations semantically. While      authors can include the  (xmlelement)_10_mathml  element directly in content, the      recommended best practice is to always include  (xmlelement)_11_mathml  within one of      the equation domain elements or their semantic equivalent in a non-OASIS-defined DITA      vocabulary.                 (dt)_12_Equation domain       Provides the  (xmlelement)_13_equation-inline ,        (xmlelement)_14_equation-block , and  (xmlelement)_15_equation-figure       elements. This domain can be used independently of the MathML domain. The elements in the      equation domain enable authors to clearly distinguish equations from other type of content;      these markup distinctions can enable formatting distinctions, numbering of equations, and more.

text: (shortdesc)_1_The release management domain provides markup that enables content 	 developers to log information about changes that have been made to a DITA topic 	 or map. title: ( title)_0_release management domain
text: (p)_2_Processors can gather the information and assemble it into an appendix 		  or separate document, thus eliminating the need for separate release-note 		  topics or external tracking mechanisms such as spread sheets or databases. 		  Regulated industries can use the release management domain to provide the 		  records that are required by regulatory agencies.   		 (p)_3_This figure shows the structure of the release management elements.   		   		   (title)_4_Release management elements   		     			  (alt)_5_Tree structure diagram showing the 				elements available in the release management domain, their relationships to 				each other, and where they can be used in a DITA topic. The change-historylist 				element can appear in the prolog and can contain change-items. The following 				elements are children of change-item: change-person, change-organization, 				change-revisionid, change-request-reference, change-started, change-summary, 				data. The change-request-reference element can have children 				change-request-system and change-request-id.   		     		   		 (p)_6_The following list provides a brief description of the element:   		   		     			  (xmlelement)_7_change-historylist   			    			  Contains  (xmlelement)_8_change-item  elements, each of 				which represents a  				 (term)_9_release note , which is information about a single 				change  			    		     		     			  (xmlelement)_10_change-item   			    			  (dd)_11_Contains information about a release note   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_12_change-person   			    			  (dd)_13_Contains the name of a person who made the change   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_14_change-organization   			    			  (dd)_15_Contains the name of the organization that requested the change   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_16_change-revisionid   			    			  (dd)_17_Contains an identifier that is associated with the change   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_18_change-request-reference   			    			  (dd)_19_Contains information that provides traceablity to an external 				change request or other ticketing system   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_20_change-request-system   			    			  (dd)_21_Contains the name of the external system that is referenced   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_22_change-request-id   			    			  (dd)_23_Contains an identifier that is associated with the change 				request, such as an issue ID or ticket number   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_24_change-started   			    			  (dd)_25_Contains a string that holds date and time information about when 				the change was started   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_26_change-completed   			    			  (dd)_27_Contains a string that holds date and time information about when 				the change was finished   		     		     			  (xmlelement)_28_change-summary   			    			  (dd)_29_Contains a descriptive summary of the change   		     		   	    	    		 (p)_30_This figure shows three simple change-items added to a single topic. title: ( title)_0_technical content specialization
text: (shortdesc)_1_This section contains information about the technical content specializations. It   includes a summary of the document types and domains, as well as information about how the   technical content specializations support authoring troubleshooting information.

title: ( title)_0_troubleshoot information
text: (shortdesc)_1_Troubleshooting information is invaluable to technical content users because it     provides advice to correct problems with task performance.
subject: information

title: ( title)_0_troubleshoot information
text:
(p)_2_User studies show that users find troubleshooting information invaluable because they frequently access technical information only when they have encountered a problem in performing a task. (p)_3_The DITA troubleshooting elements added in DITA 1.3 encourage authors to provide troubleshooting information directly within a task, at the point of need, and to label the troubleshooting information appropriately. Minimalism research indicates that users are most likely to read troubleshooting information if it is visibly labeled. We recommend that implementations use style sheets that add symbols or text to draw attention to the troubleshooting elements in the topics. Troubleshooting information can be added to an individual step in a DITA task; it also can be added after the steps are completed. Troubleshooting information can be added in any topic type in a (xmlelement)_4_note element with the (xmlatt)_5_type attribute set to "trouble". However, we recommend that users use either (xmlelement)_6_steptroubleshooting or (xmlelement)_7_tasktroubleshooting when working on a task topic, rather than inserting an (xmlelement)_8_note element with the (xmlatt)_9_type attribute set to "trouble". (p)_10_The examples below illustrate the three options. (title)_11_Step troubleshooting (p)_12_Troubleshooting information can be added following a step in a procedure if it is likely that the user will encounter a problem in performing the step. The (xmlelement)_13_steptroubleshooting element can occur following the (xmlelement)_14_cmd element in the (xmlelement)_15_step or (xmlelement)_16_substep element. The (xmlelement)_17_steptroubleshooting element ends the (xmlelement)_18_step or (xmlelement)_19_substep element. Another element, such as (xmlelement)_20_info or (xmlelement)_21_stepxmp , cannot be added after the (xmlelement)_22_steptroubleshooting element. (p)_23_The first example shows troubleshooting information added to a step. The second example shows the troubleshooting information following a step result. (codeblock)_24_ Select Shut Down from the File Menu. If a problem with the computer prevents you from choosing Shut Downfor example, if the computer freezes so that the pointer does not respond to the trackpadyou can turn off the computer by holding down the Control, Option, Command, and Power On keys at the same time. (codeblock)_25_ Select the element for which you want to assign a conditional- processing attribute, and, in the Attributes window, select the conditional-processing attribute. The permissible values for the attribute are displayed in a drop-down list. If the list of controlled values is not displayed, ensure that the root map is opened in the DITA Maps Manager window. (title)_26_Task troubleshooting Troubleshooting information can be added after the procedural component to assist the user in correcting a problem that might have occurred. The (xmlelement)_27_tasktroubleshooting element is one of four optional elements that can follow the (xmlelement)_28_steps element. When these optional element are used, they must appear in the following order: (xmlelement)_29_results , (xmlelement)_30_tasktroubleshooting , (xmlelement)_31_example , and (xmlelement)_32_postreq . (codeblock)_33_ When the fast blinking stops, press small espresso. If the small espresso button is not lit, recycle the unit by turning the external Power off and on. We recommend that DITA implementations configure their CSS or stylesheets to include appropriate text or an icon in the generated output. Best practices for authoring DITA content mandate that the troubleshooting note should not be used in place of (xmlelement)_37_steptroubleshooting or (xmlelement)_38_tasktroubleshooting in a task topic. If you expose your camera to sudden changes in temperature or humidity, you might experience some condensation in the camera. Aavoid the possibility of condensation because it might result in soil on the lens or the monitor, cause mold, or damage the camera.

If you do get condensation, turn off the camera and wait about two hours before using it. Once the camera adjusts to the surrounding temperature, the fogging will clear naturally.
