title: ( title)_0_xnal usage guideline
text: (shortdesc)_1_Extended information and usage examples for DITA bookmap metadata 	 elements associated with OASIS xNAL Standard (extensible Name and Address 	 Language).

title: ( title)_0_xnal usage guideline
text: DITA bookmaps use a set of 		elements associated with a subset of the  		 (xref)_2_OASIS extensible 		  Name and Address Language (xNAL)  specification (Version 2) to denote 		name and address information related to persons and organizations.  	    	  While the elements share element names, and the 			expectation is that content written using this type of metadata  (ph)_3_is  be straightforward to transform, the element name 			pairs do not share content models. The difference in content models reflects the 			different purposes of the two standards. The purpose of the name and address elements in 			DITA is to identify persons or organizations associated with the creation of a document; 			the purpose of the name and address elements in xNAL is to support customer resource 			management.    	  (p)_4_The examples shown after the 		table provide sample tagging methods for name and address information, using 		the DITA elements associated with xNAL.   	    		 (title)_5_DITA elements associated with xNAL elements   		 The set of bookmap elements 		  associated with elements from the  		   (xref)_6_OASIS extensible 			 Name and Address Language (xNAL)  standard are listed in the table below. 		   		   		  		 (title)_7_DITA elements associated with xNAL elements   		   		     			    				 (xmlelement)_11_addressdetails  				   				 (xmlelement)_12_honorific  				   				 (xmlelement)_13_otherinfo  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_14_administrativearea  				   				 (xmlelement)_15_lastname  				   				 (xmlelement)_16_person  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_17_authorinformation  				   				 (xmlelement)_18_locality  				   				 (xmlelement)_19_personinfo  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_20_contactnumber  				   				 (xmlelement)_21_localityname  				   				 (xmlelement)_22_personname  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_23_contactnumbers  				   				 (xmlelement)_24_middlename  				   				 (xmlelement)_25_postalcode  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_26_country  				   				 (xmlelement)_27_namedetails  				   				 (xmlelement)_28_thoroughfare  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_29_emailaddress  				   				 (xmlelement)_30_organization  				   				 (xmlelement)_31_url  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_32_emailaddresses  				   				 (xmlelement)_33_organizationinfo  				   				 (xmlelement)_34_urls  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_35_firstname  				   				 (xmlelement)_36_organizationname  				   			    			    				 (xmlelement)_37_generationidentifier  				   				 (xmlelement)_38_organizationnamedetails  				   				 (entry)_39_   			    		     		   		   	    	    		 (title)_40_Example 1: Tagging personal information in DITA   		 (p)_41_This example shows a way to 		  tag the following personal name and description.   		 (lines)_42_Mr. Ram V. Kumar Jr. Chief Technologist MSI Business Solutions   		 (codeblock)_43_<authorinformation>   <personinfo>     <namedetails>       <personname>         <honorific>Mr.</honorific>         <firstname>Ram</firstname>         <middlename>V.</middlename>         <lastname>Kumar</lastname>         <generationidentifier>Jr.</generationidentifier>         <otherinfo>Chief Technologist</otherinfo>       </personname>     </namedetails>   </personinfo>   <organizationinfo>     <namedetails>       <organizationnamedetails>         <organizationname>MSI Business Solutions</organizationname>       </organizationnamedetails>     </namedetails>   </organizationinfo> </authorinformation>   	    	    		 (title)_44_Example 2: Tagging address information in DITA   		 (p)_45_This example shows a way to 		  tag the following address.   		 (lines)_46_23 Archer St. Chatsworth NSW 2067 Australia   		 (codeblock)_47_<addressdetails>   <thoroughfare>123 Archer St.</thoroughfare>   <locality>     <localityname>Chatsworth</localityname>     <postalcode>2067</postalcode>   </locality>   <administrativearea>NSW</administrativearea>   <country>Australia</country> </addressdetails>   	    	    		 (title)_48_Example 3: Tagging complex name and address information in 		  DITA   		 (p)_49_This example shows two ways to 		  tag a fairly complex collection of personal, organizational, and address 		  information.   		 (lines)_50_Mr. Samuel L. Johnson Jr. Chief Technologist c/o XYZ Corporation 52 New Main St.  Carrboro,  NC  27510  USA email: johnson@example.com phone: 919-555-7987   		 (p)_51_This method tags all the 		  organizational information as associated with the identified person.   		 (codeblock)_52_<personinfo>    <namedetails>       <personname>           <firstname>Samuel</firstname>           <middlename>L.</middlename>           <lastname>Johnson</lastname>           <generationidentifier>Jr.</generationidentifier>           <otherinfo>Chief Technologist</otherinfo>           <otherinfo>c/o XYZ Corporation </otherinfo>       </personname>    </namedetails>    <addressdetails>       <thoroughfare>52 New Main St.</thoroughfare>       <locality>          <localityname>Carrboro</localityname>          <postalcode>27510</postalcode>       </locality>       <administrativearea>NC</administrativearea>       <country>USA</country>    </addressdetails>    <contactnumbers>       <contactnumber>919-555-7987</contactnumber>    </contactnumbers>    <emailaddresses>       <emailaddress>johnson@example.com</emailaddress>    </emailaddresses> </personinfo>   		 (p)_53_The following method separates 		  the person and organization information. It might be used if it were necessary 		  to associate address information with organizations rather than persons.   		 (codeblock)_54_<authorinformation>   <personinfo>     <namedetails>       <personname>         <firstname>Samuel</firstname>         <middlename>L.</middlename>         <lastname>Johnson</lastname>         <generationidentifier>Jr.</generationidentifier>         <otherinfo>Chief Technologist</otherinfo>       </personname>     </namedetails>     <contactnumbers>       <contactnumber>919-555-7987</contactnumber>     </contactnumbers>     <emailaddresses>       <emailaddress>johnson@example.com</emailaddress>     </emailaddresses>   </personinfo>     <organizationinfo>     <namedetails>       <organizationnamedetails>         <organizationname>XYZ Corporation</organizationname>         <otherinfo>c/o </otherinfo>       </organizationnamedetails>     </namedetails>     <addressdetails>       <thoroughfare>52 New Main St.</thoroughfare>       <locality>          <localityname>Carrboro</localityname>          <postalcode>27510</postalcode>       </locality>       <administrativearea>NC</administrativearea>       <country>USA</country>     </addressdetails>   </organizationinfo> </authorinformation>

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: (shortdesc)_1_The DITA xNAL domain specialization defines a number of metadata 	 elements and attributes that are useful in representing personal/organizational 	 names and addresses. The metadata can be used to identify authors and content 	 owners. The OASIS xNAL Standard (extensible Name and Address Langauge) was 	 selected to represent close mappings from the DITA bookmap metadata content 	 model to an existing standard. xNAL is included in the Bookmap and the 	 LearningBookmap document types.
subject: shortdesc)_1_the dita xnal domain specialization
metadata
oasis xnal standard
xnal

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: The OASIS Customer Information 		Quality (CIQ) standard for global-customer information management contains the 		definition of the  		 (xref)_2_OASIS extensible Name and Address Language (xNAL)  		metadata elements. Version 2 of the standard states: 	    	    		 (p)_3_The objective of xNAL is to 		  describe a common structure for Personal/Organization Names and Addresses that 		  would enable any applications that want to represent customer names and 		  addresses in a common standard format. The applications could be CRM/e-CRM, 		  Customer Information Systems, Data Quality (Parsing, Matching, Validation, 		  Verification, etc.), Customer Data Warehouses, Postal services, etc.   		 However, any party for its own purposes and 				applications  (ph)_4_can  use xNAL grammar or parts of it.    	    	  (p)_5_The DITA xNAL specialization is 		based on the OASIS extensible Name and Address Language metadata elements. Due 		to differences between the two processing architectures, the DITA xNAL domain 		does not incorporate all of the definitions from the OASIS xNAL standard 		directly. Instead, there is a transformational equivalence between 		the DITA and OASIS xNAL definitions for names and addresses. This equivalence 		enables XML-aware tools in workflow systems to capture and manipulate names and 		addresses in a standard manner.   	  The xNAL domain is available for 		use in the  (xmlelement)_6_bookmap  and 		 (xmlelement)_7_learningBookmap  document types, which are distributed 		as part of the DITA 1.3 specification. It can be included in specialized DITA 		document types that require metadata for names and addresses.

text: (title)_2_The purpose of the concept information type   		 Concepts provide background that helps readers 				understand essential information about a product, a task, a process, or any other 				conceptual or descriptive information.

title: ( title)_0_concept topic
text: Conceptual information helps readers to map their knowledge and 				understanding to the tasks they need to perform and to provide other essential 				information about a product, process, or system.

Bird songs vary widely among species, from simple songs that are genetically imprinted to complex songs that are learned over a lifetime.

title: ( title)_0_general task topic
text: (title)_2_The purpose of the general task information type   		 (p)_3_Like the DITA strict task document type, the general task document and information types 				contain the essential building blocks to provide procedural information.
subject: general task document and information type

title: ( title)_0_general task topic
text: Both task 				information types answer the "How do I?" question by providing step-by-step 				instructions that detail the requirements that must be fulfilled, the actions that 				must be performed, and the order in which the actions must be performed.
subject: information type
action

text: Both task 				topics include sections for describing the context, prerequisites, expected results, 				and other aspects of a task.
subject: task 				 topic

title: ( title)_0_general task topic
text: The general task information type is specifically 				designed to accommodate task specializations that differ from the DITA task 				information type.
subject: general task information type

title: ( title)_0_general task topic
text: It  (ph)_4_might  also be used for the 				conversion of loosely structured tasks from other sources into DITA before they are 				restructured to follow the more restrictive DITA task model.

subject: general task topic

text: (xmlelement)_18_steps-informal  			    			  Describes procedural task information that would not normally be ordered as 							 (xmlelement)_19_steps , such as a group of general procedures 						that  (ph)_20_might  all be applied in a particular 						situation.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: (xmlelement)_1_glossentry  topic defines a single sense of     one term.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Besides identifying the term and providing a definition, the topic accommodates basic     terminology information, such as part of speech.
subject: topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: A glossentry topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: (ph)_2_might  also include acronyms and acronym expansions.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Glossentry topics can be assembled     by authors or processes to create glossaries for various purposes, including books, websites, or     other projects.
subject: glossentry topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: (title)_3_The purpose of the glossary entry topic         (p)_4_Defining terminology in a glossary ensures that a team of writers uses the same term for         the same concept.
subject: title)_3_the purpose
p)_4_defin terminology
team

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: A glossary added to a book or available online in conjunction with other         subject matter provides the reader with definitions of unfamiliar terms and expands         acronyms.          1.
subject: glossary

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: from  jeff ogden: Say a little more.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Say that collections of glossary  entries are assembled into collections of terms when they are      referenced from a map.
subject: collection

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Say that the Glossary topic type was originally  created for use with bookmap, but can be used elsewhere.
subject: glossary topic type

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: MP  response: reluctant to say either - I'm not clear on what special  processing maps could/would provide.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Added a paragraph with the  simple case (just author a glossary) below.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: On the "originally created  for bookmap" front, I'm not sure I agree - one of the requirements  going in from an IBM perspective was for  online glossaries rather  than book-based ones.

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: 3.MP: per jeff ogden  and per stan doherty, provided some extra text to clarify that  glossary topics do go into      glossaries
subject: glossary topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: (title)_5_The structure of the glossentry topic         The top-level element for a DITA glossentry topic is the  (xmlelement)_6_glossentry          element.
subject: title)_5_the structure

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Every glossentry topic contains a  (xmlelement)_7_glossterm  and a  (xmlelement)_8_glossdef  element and         optional  (xmlelement)_9_related-links .
subject: glossentry topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Where a term has multiple definitions,  (ph)_10_best practices call for           the writer to  create multiple glossentry topics with the same term in the            (xmlelement)_11_glossterm  element but different definitions in the            (xmlelement)_12_glossdef  element.
subject: term
ph)_10_best practice
writer

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: A process can collate and group glossentry         topics by term when generating formatted output.
subject: process

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Note that definitions with the same term in         one language can have different terms in other languages, so translations can result in         different collation and grouping of the same set of glossentry topics.
subject: definition
translation

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: (p)_13_Here is an example of a simple glossentry topic:         (codeblock)_14_<glossentry id="ddl">     <glossterm>Data Definition Language</glossterm>     <glossdef>

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: A language used for defining database schemas.</glossdef>

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: </glossentry>         To create a glossary, authors can group multiple entries together by             (li)_15_authoring in a single document using the Glossary group document type             (li)_16_authoring in a single document under a container topic using the ditabase document             type             (li)_17_referencing the glossentry topics from a map             (li)_18_using an automated process           For example, an automated process  (ph)_19_might  assemble         glossentry topics from a repository based on the  (xmlelement)_20_term  markup in a         particular collection of topics.
subject: author

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: Jeff Ogden 2007/01/22: made authoring option using ditabase explicit; made automated processing       option clearer with an example

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: (title)_21_Acronyms defined within glossentry topics         The glossentry topic  (ph)_22_can  be used to provide expansions of         acronyms in online text and assist in the proper translation of acronyms into multiple         languages.
subject: glossentry topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic
text: The acronym elements of the glossentry topic include the following:             (li)_23_<glossterm> to enter the full text to which the acronym refers             (li)_24_<glossSurfaceForm> to provide the appropriate rendering of the full text plus the             acronym in each language             (li)_25_<glossAcronym> to provide the acronym text itself                   (p)_26_Here is an example of an acronym used in the glossentry topic:         (codeblock)_27_<glossentry id="wmd" xml:lang="en">   <glossterm>Weapons of Mass Destruction</glossterm>   <glossBody>     <
subject: acronym element
acronym

text: glossSurfaceForm>Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD)</glossSurfaceForm>     <glossAlt>       <glossAcronym>WMD</glossAcronym>     </glossAlt

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic

subject: glossentry topic

title: ( title)_0_glossary entry topic

element

subject: acronym

text: (title)_2_The purpose of the machinery task information type                  (p)_3_The machinery-task is designed to provide procedural information, similar to the                     strict task topic, and has a well-defined semantic structure that describes how                     to perform the steps required to accomplish a specific goal.
subject: p)_3_the machinery - task

title: ( title)_0_machinery task topic
text: Compared to the                     strict task information type, the machinery-task information type contains                     additional descriptive elements in the prelreqs section that add detail to the                     pre-requisites required to perform a task.

title: ( title)_0_machinery task topic

subject: p)_4_machinery task

title: ( title)_0_machinery task topic
text: A                     machinery-task information type answers the "How do I?"

title: ( title)_0_machinery task topic

subject: question
action

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: (title)_2_Purpose of the reference topic  			 (p)_3_Reference topics provide data that supports users as they perform a task.
subject: p)_3_reference topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: Reference 				topics might provide lists and tables that include product specifications, parts 				lists, and other data that is often looked up rather than memorized.
subject: reference 				 topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: A reference 				topic also can describe commands in a programming language or required tools for a 				series of maintenance tasks.
subject: reference 				 topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: (p)_4_Reference topics provide quick access to fact-based information.
subject: p)_4_reference topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: In technical 				information, reference topics are used to list product specifications and 				parameters, provide essential data, and provide detailed information on subjects 				such as the commands in a programming language.
subject: reference topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: Reference topics can contain any 				subject matter that has regular content, such as ingredients for food in recipes, 				bibliographic lists, catalog items, and so on.
subject: reference topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: (title)_5_The structure of the reference topic  			 The top-level element for a reference topic is the  (xmlelement)_6_reference  				element.   			 The  (xmlelement)_7_refbody  element contains the main body-level elements of 				the reference topic.
subject: title)_5_the structure
xmlelement)_7_refbody   element

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: Reference topics limit the body to tables (both simple and 				complex), property lists, syntax sections, generic sections, and examples.
subject: reference topic

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: All of the elements of  (xmlelement)_8_refbody  are optional; they  (ph)_9_can  appear in any sequence and number.

title: ( title)_0_reference topic
text: (title)_10_Limitations on the reference body  			 The  (xmlelement)_11_refbody  provides for an unlimited number of subdivisions in the 				form of sections, examples, syntax sections, property lists, and tables.
subject: xmlelement)_11_refbody

title: ( title)_0_reference topic

additional section

title: ( title)_0_bookmap
text: (title)_2_The purpose of the bookmap specialization         (p)_3_Books and other printed media are popular ways to present DITA content.
subject: title)_2_the purpose

title: ( title)_0_bookmap
text: By specializing the         general DITA map structure into the general structure and subject areas used by most         book-oriented DTDs, bookmaps enable users to organize their DITA information into front         matter, parts, chapters, and so forth.
subject: general dita map structure
book - orient dtd

title: ( title)_0_bookmap
text: A rich set of metadata allows for recording         information about the book, such as its authors and owners, versions, and production         history.
subject: rich set

text: (title)_4_The structure of the bookmap specialization         The  (xmlelement)_5_bookmap  element is the top-level element for a DITA bookmap.
subject: xmlelement)_5_bookmap   element

text: (ph)_1_troubleshooting , glossary entry, and 	 glossary group.

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: These document types are designed specifically for information 	 that describes how to use products and processes.
subject: document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The Technical Content package 	 also includes the map document type.
subject: technical content package

SVO: concept document type provides conceptual information
title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
Concept

The concept document type provides conceptual information designed to support the performance of tasks.
subject: concept document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: Concepts might include extended definitions of terms, expositions of background information, descriptions of systems and objects, and other content that helps to build the users' understanding of the tasks to be perform.
subject: concept

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: <section id="section_7B61E25E4D254890AAD883F94FBD116F"><title>Reference</title><p

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: id="p_FEE53D6D22354D698D3092786A701647">The reference document type provides for the separation of fact-based information from concepts and tasks. Factual information might include tables and lists of specifications, parameters, parts, commands, and other information that the users are likely to look up.
subject: reference document type
factual information
user

SVO: reference document type enables based content maintained
title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The reference document type enables fact-based content to be maintained by those responsible for its accuracy and consistency.
subject: type

( title)_0_technical content : document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
>Task (strict task)

The task document type provides procedural information to support the performance of a task.
subject:
strict task)

task document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The task document type is built by combining the general-task document type and the strict <xmlelement>taskbody</xmlelement> constraint.
subject: task document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: This information model provides detailed semantics to encourage authors to label standard parts of the task, including prerequisites, sufficient conceptual information required to perform the task, the commands that introduce each step in a procedure, additional support information required to understand a step, the result of performing the task, and examples that demonstrate the performance of the task.
subject: information model

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type

SVO: task document type provides less strict model
title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
General task

The general-task document type provides a less strict task model for task-oriented information than that provided in the strict task.
subject: general - task document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: Some organizations might prefer the general task model; it can facilitate the migration of legacy task content that does not follow the strict task topic model.
subject: organization

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The general-task document type serves as the base for the strict task and machine-industry-task document types.
subject: general - task document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
>For historical reasons and to maintain backward compatibility, the names used for the various task components can be confusing:

  • General task is the name for the general task document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
• Task is the name for the strict task document type
  • Task is also the name for the general task information type
  • Task is the name of the specialized topic tag in the general information type which is used in the strict task, general task, and machine-industry task document types
subject: task
task
> task

SVO: machinery task document type provides procedural information similar
it has well defined semantic structure
title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
Machinery task

The machinery-task document type provides procedural information, similar to other task types; it has a well-defined semantic structure to meet the special requirements of organizations that develop instructional material for industrial equipment, such as trucks, mining machinery, and automobiles.
subject: machinery - task document type

SVO: machine industry task requirements domain adds several descriptive elements
title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The machine-industry task requirements domain adds several descriptive elements in the preliminary requirements (<xmlelement>prelreqs</xmlelement>) and closing requirements (<xmlelement>closereqs</xmlelement>) sections.
subject: machine - industry task requirement domain

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The machinery-task document type is built by combining the general-task document type with the task requirements domain and the machinery <xmlelement>taskbody</xmlelement> constraint.
subject: machinery - task document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
( title)_0_technical content : document type
text:
Troubleshooting

The troubleshooting document type provides markup for corrective action information such as troubleshooting and alarm clearing.
subject: section rev="dita1.3 proposal-13097
troubleshooting document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The troubleshooting information type describes a condition or a symptom, after which it provides one or more possible causes and their associated remedies.
subject: troubleshooting information type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: Each remedy is a series of steps, associated with a cause, that attempts to resolve the condition or symptom.
subject: remedy

( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: Glossary entry

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The glossary entry (<xmlelement>glossentry</xmlelement

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: >) document type enables authors to develop glossary topics that define terms, acronyms, and abbreviations.
subject: document type

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: It also can contain terminology information.

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: Glossary group

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: The glossary group (<xmlelement>glossgroup</xmlelement

title: ( title)_0_technical content : document type
text: >) document type enables authors to incorporate multiple glossary entries in a single collection tile.
subject: document type

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization
text: The objectives of the specializations include the following:   Provide a general top-level design for authoring of education content with good learning architecture, following DITA principles and best practices.

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization
text: Some specifics of good DITA design for learning content include:    (li)_2_offer a starter set of specialized topic types that support structured, intent-based authoring of content for learning and training, including assessments   provide a map domain for structuring  (ph)_3_and storing  the specialized          learning topics as reusable learning objects, and for managing the linking and          relationships among them   (li)_4_offers basic map-driven processing to support topic linking, relationships, and simple sequencing   (li)_5_includes a starter set of commonly-used learning interactions, for use in testing and assessment   (li)_6_provides support for learning metadata based on the IEEE standard for learning objects metadata (LOM), for use in both topics and maps         Establish guidelines that promote best practices for applying standard DITA approaches to learning content, which include:    (li)_7_separation of presentation and content (as much as possible)   (li)_8_separation of content and context   (li)_9_single sourcing, repurposing, and reuse       (li)_10_Provide basic support for processing DITA content for delivery as learning and training in a variety of forms, including print and presentation delivery to support instructor-led training (ILT) and web delivery for distance learning.
subject: specific
( li)_7_separation

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization
text: (li)_11_Provide a framework for developing targeted support for processing DITA learning content for delivery with standards-based learning, specifically targeting SCORM.

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization

title: ( title)_0_objectif dita learning and training specialization
text: (note)_13_Simply using the content models described in this specification, of course, does not ensure quality learning content.

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (p)_2_Today's learners confront a complex world with many inter-related bits and pieces of information, many different ways to access that information, and a strong need to identify the connection points, the objectives, and the context for what to know and what to learn.
subject: p)_2_today 's learner

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: In this environment, developers of learning and training content face many challenges, including:   (li)_3_How to find the context for developing and delivering the right content to the right person at the right time?
subject: developer

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_4_How to identify the learning goals and objectives?   (li)_5_Who and how many are the audiences?

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_6_How to pull together and integrate content from many different sources and content providers?

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_7_How to enable customers and partners to add, integrate, assemble, and deliver their own content?
subject: li)_7_how

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: These key challenges and issues for delivery of learning and training content mirror long-standing pain points and requirements for content delivery in general.

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_8_Content consumers value consistency of content and learning experiences.

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_9_They desire management of content to make it shareable across and within teams.

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_10_They seek to simplify the information needed to support the complex environments.

title: ( title)_0_overview
text: (li)_11_Finally, they want a content development process that can enable the assembly and delivery of custom content that addresses specific learning contexts and use cases.

subject: p)_2_the dita 1.3 domain

text: (p)_7_If you have already implemented learning and 			training support with DITA 1.2 and none of the limitations adversely affected your 			support, then you can continue to use the learningDomain in document types that need 			assessments.

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: (dt)_4_Creating custom courses quickly        (dd)_5_A company has a large inventory of topic-based content that is used to provide technical       and troubleshooting information about a set of componentized software products.

text: The company       wants to enable field engineers to quickly identify technical content that is suitable for       providing on-site training.
subject: company

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: The DITA learning and training specializations enable field       engineers to draw on their inventory of topics and quickly assemble learning content to meet       specific customer needs.
subject: dita learning and training specialization

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: (dt)_6_Making technical content available for direct sharing and reuse in learning and       training        (dd)_7_A DITA learning specialization makes it possible to define a context for and directly       assemble and use existing technical content for delivery as learning and training.
subject: dd)_7_a dita learn specialization
context

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: The DITA       approach identifies consistent structures and patterns and leverages them to enable a       consistent approach for sharing content across teams.
subject: dita        approach

title: ( title)_0_use case
text: As a result, instead       of copy, paste, and make unique as the norm, we have write once and share with others as the       new norm.

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: Version 2 of the standard states:

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: (p)_3_The objective of xNAL is to 		  describe a common structure for Personal/Organization Names and Addresses that 		  would enable any applications that want to represent customer names and 		  addresses in a common standard format.
subject: p)_3_the objective

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: The applications could be CRM/e-CRM, 		  Customer Information Systems, Data Quality (Parsing, Matching, Validation, 		  Verification, etc.), Customer Data Warehouses, Postal services, etc.
subject: application

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: However, any party for its own purposes and 				applications  (ph)_4_can  use xNAL grammar or parts of it.

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: (p)_5_The DITA xNAL specialization is 		based on the OASIS extensible Name and Address Language metadata elements.
object: oasis extensible and address language metadata element
subject: p)_5_the dita xnal specialization

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: Due 		to differences between the two processing architectures, the DITA xNAL domain 		does not incorporate all of the definitions from the OASIS xNAL standard 		directly.
subject: dita xnal domain

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: Instead, there is a transformational equivalence between 		the DITA and OASIS xNAL definitions for names and addresses.

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: This equivalence 		enables XML-aware tools in workflow systems to capture and manipulate names and 		addresses in a standard manner.
subject: equivalence

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: The xNAL domain is available for 		use in the  (xmlelement)_6_bookmap  and 		 (xmlelement)_7_learningBookmap  document types, which are distributed 		as part of the DITA 1.3 specification.
subject: xnal domain

title: ( title)_0_the xnal domain
text: It can be included in specialized DITA 		document types that require metadata for names and addresses.
